content: In this section, we review major environmental impacts of agriculture, including land use, energy consumption, and greenhouse gases. We review farming's water needs separately.
Agriculture is the largest land use impact that humans exert [owid_landuse].
-land_use.jpg-60
!See our land use analysis for more information on data sources.
Since 1961, world cropland area has been steadily growing, while pasture land may have peaked [peak_farmland].
-ag_land_trends.jpg-60
!Source: FAOSTAT [faostat].
Following are estimates of land use required by particular crops.
-area_by_crop.jpg-60

!Area needs of plant-based crops are taken from FAOSTAT [faostat], with their Nutritive Factors database [nutritive] to convert to a calorie basis. Area needs for meat is taken from Clark and Tilman [meat_land_use]. Fish are assumed to be produced through aquaculture, using the area estimates to grow feedstock for the United States, as reported by Froehlich et al. [aq_land_use].
sections.name: Agricultural Land Use

content: Agriculture, including upstream energy to manufacture equipment, fertilizers, and pesticides, accounts for about 4% of world energy consumption.
-energy_in_ag.jpg
!Sources: Audsley et al. [audsley], Bennetzen et al. [bennetzen], Building Energy Codes Program [energycode], FAOSTAT [faostat], IRRI [irri].

Wealthier countries tend to have higher crop yields and higher energy inputs, suggesting a tradeoff between land use and energy consumption in agriculture [schneider_smith]. In 2011, energy accounted for over 30% of corn, sorghum, and rice production costs [ag_energy_demand], underscoring the importance of energy as a factor in food affordability.
The growing of crops is just a portion of energy consumption in the larger food system.
sections.name: Energy in Agriculture

content: Agriculture is responsible for about 20% of world greenhouse gas emissions.
-ghg_ag.jpg-60
!Sources of greenhouse gases worldwide, with warming potential assessed by carbon dioxide equivalency. Source: FAOSTAT [faostat].
Other aspects of the world food system, such as packaging and transportation, contribute 15-25% of the emissions detailed above [world_ag_emissions].
